description:
Kyon, your typical high school student, has long given up his belief in the supernatural. However, upon meeting Haruhi Suzumiya, he quickly finds out that it is the supernatural that she is interested in; aliens, time travelers and espers among other things. When Haruhi laments about the lack of intriguing clubs around school, Kyon inspires Haruhi to form her own club. As a result, the SOS Brigade is formed, a club which specializes in all that is the supernatural.

Much to his chagrin, Kyon, along with the silent bookworm, Yuki Nagato, the shy and timid Mikuru Asahina, and the perpetually smiling Itsuki Koizumi, are recruited as members. The story follows the crazy adventures that these four endure under their whimsical leader, Haruhi. The story is based on the light novels by Nagaru Tanigawa.

Note: This entry is for the original 14-episode 2006 airing. The series was further expanded and reordered into a 28-episode series in 2009.

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Achronological Order
tags.description: Chapters or episodes do not occur in chronological order.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Filmmaking
tags.description: Centers around the art of filmmaking.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Baseball
tags.description: Centers around the sport of baseball.

tags.name: Maids
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a maid.

name.native: コンピュータ研究会部長

node.description:
__Height:__ 157 cm (5'2")

[Blog](http://ameblo.jp/hirano--aya/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/hysteric_barbie) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/a_ya.hirano/) | [Website](http://ayahirano.jp/)

Aya Hirano is a Japanese actress, voice actress, and singer. Beginning in the entertainment industry as a child actor performing in television commercials, she played her first voice acting role in 2001 in the anime television series [Angel Tales](https://anilist.co/anime/682/). She released her first single "Breakthrough" in 2006, and her first album Riot Girl in 2008. She was formerly contracted to Space Craft Produce, a branch of the Space Craft Group, before moving to the talent agency Grick in August 2011. Her label was Lantis until 2011, when she moved to Universal Sigma. On September 1st, 2022, she announced that she was becoming a freelancer. 

Hirano is widely known for her roles as [Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/character/251/) in the [Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/) franchise, [Konata Izumi](https://anilist.co/character/2169/) in [Lucky Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1887/), [Misa Amane](https://anilist.co/character/835/) in [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/) and [Lucy Heartfilia](https://anilist.co/character/5186/) in [Fairy Tail](https://anilist.co/anime/6702/).

In 2011, she temporarily ceased accepting new roles to recover from a pituitary gland tumor that had been affecting her health. She resumed voice acting activities later that year. In 2016, after appearing at a stage play in Tokyo, she went to New York to study abroad for four months.

__Awards:__
- Best Voice Actor at the Tokyo Anime Awards in 2007 for her role as Haruhi Suzumiya.
- Best Rookie Actress at the 1st Seiyuu Awards in 2007 for her role as Haruhi Suzumiya.
- Best Lead Actress at the 2nd Seiyuu Awards in 2008 for her roles as Konata Izumi, Misa Amane and [Layla Serizawa](https://anilist.co/character/2089/)

(Source: Wikipedia)

__Height:__ 158cm
__Nickname:__ Minorin (みのりん)

[Official Website](https://www.minorichihara.com/) | [Profile (HoriPro)](http://www.horipro-international.com/artist/chihara) | [Website (Lantis)](https://www.lantis.jp/artist/chiharaminori/) | [Blog](https://lineblog.me/minori_parade/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/minori_contact) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/minori_chihara/) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minori_Chihara) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/茅原実里)

Minori Chihara is a Japanese voice actress and singer.

On April 2, 2021, she announced via her blog that she was taking an indefinite hiatus on her singing activities at the end of the year, but continuing to voice act.

__Height:__ 163cm
__Hobbies:__ Motorcycle, reading, traveling

[Profile (Axl One)](http://www.axl-one.com/talent/goto.html) | [Profile (Lantis)](https://lantis.jp/artist/gotoyuko/) | [Blog](http://ameblo.jp/goto-yuko) | [Website](http://gotu-web.cafe.coocan.jp/) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yūko_Gotō) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/後藤邑子)

Nagaru is a Japanese author, best known as the creator of the [Suzumiya Haruhi series](https://anilist.co/manga/33083/Suzumiya-Haruhi-Series/). 

In high school, he was part of an art club but would also visit a literary club once a week. He graduated from the Faculty of Law in Kwansei Gakuin University. After graduating from university, he became a manager at a women's clothing store but decided to quit to pursue a writing career.

He would spend time being unemployed and reading books at the library, until he made his debut in March 2003 with his novel "Dengeki!! Aegis 5" in the magazine "Dengeki Moeou". That same year, two of his other novels [Escape From School!](https://anilist.co/manga/40275/Gakkou-wo-Deyou/) and [The Melancholy of Suzumiya Haruhi](https://anilist.co/manga/33083/Suzumiya-Haruhi-Series/) were released, with The Melancholy of Suzumiya Haruhi winning the Sneaker Taisho literary prize.

His work is strongly influenced by the science fiction novels he read while in middle school. He has mentioned that authors who influenced him in particular were [Hideyuki Kikuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97323/Hideyuki-Kikuchi/), [Baku Yumemakura](https://anilist.co/staff/97026/Baku-Yumemakura/), [Ellery Queen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellery_Queen), [Van Dine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._S._Van_Dine), [Isaac Asimov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Asimov), as well as the director of [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/Urusei-Yatsura/), [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/Mamoru-Oshii/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/itoww)

Artist of the Shakugan no Shana and Suzumiya Haruhi novels and the Bee-Be-Beat it! manga series. Employed under the H-game maker UNiSONSHIFT she has worked on 4 H-games: Nanatsuiro Drops, Alice Parade, Peace@Pieces, and Forget Me Not.

A prominent director and a key member of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

After graduating from Osaka Designers' College in the late '80s, Ishihara joined Kyoto Animation and began his career as an animator. In 1991, he made his debut as a director with [Shiawasette Naani](https://anilist.co/anime/13441/). After that, he switched his focus to directing. Back then Kyoto Animation was still a sub-contracting studio, so therefore Ishihara could only get a handful of opportunities directing. Some of the shows in which Ishihara got to direct multiple episodes were [Tenchi Muyou!](https://anilist.co/anime/696/), [Aka-chan to Boku](https://anilist.co/anime/1485/), [Hyper Police](https://anilist.co/anime/1180/), and [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/). He also storyboarded the majority of the episodes he directed.

In 2003, Kyoto Animation started their transformation into a full-fledged animation studio producing their first anime series, [Fullmetal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/). Ishihara directed and storyboarded the 7th episode of the show. Two years later in 2005, he made his proper directorial debut directing the studio's second TV show, [Air](https://anilist.co/anime/101/). The following year he directed the award winning anime series, [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/). From here Ishihara has gone on to direct multiple of Kyoto Animation's acclaimed works.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/3576100634)

Originating from [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

A Japanese composer and arranger. He joined NAMCO as a soundtrack composer in 1999, and then he joined MONACA Inc. as a music designer in 2004.

Soundtracks he has worked on credited as MONACA: 
- Star Driver: Kagayaki no Takuto (with Keigo Hoashi and Ryuichi Takada) 
- Hourou Musuko (with Keigo Hoashi and Keiichi Okabe) 
- A-Channel (with Kakeru Ishihama, Ryuichi Takada, Keigo Hoashi)

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

A Japanese composer and arranger. He joined NAMCO as a soundtrack composer in 1999, and then he joined MONACA Inc. as a music designer in 2004.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yamacane0901/) | [Blog (jp)](https://ameblo.jp/kanku0901/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcZ_aVrm0ux7Jw2G5jgq6Gw/)

Yutaka Yamamoto is a director, scriprtwriter, lyricist and storyboarder. Infamous for his incendiary behavior on Twitter and for having been fired from [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/) and [Ordet](https://anilist.co/studio/334/), the latter of which he helped co-found. 

As a member of Kyoto Animation, he rose to prominence within the company after serving as assistant director on [Munto 2: Beyond the Walls of Time](https://anilist.co/anime/1135/). In 2006, he was selected to be the chief episode director of [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/), after which he became well known among anime fans for the ending dance theme he choreographed. He was to make his full directorial debut with [Lucky Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1887/), but was replaced after four episodes due to "performance issues." In a later radio interview, Yamamoto confirmed he was fired by Kyoto Animation and unsuccessfully attempted to win back his job. 

Yamamoto has threatened to quit his career in anime production six times over the years. In May 2019, Yamamoto vowed never to "work on anything related to animation again" after finishing [Hakubo](https://anilist.co/anime/98784/). He has become notorious for his incendiary behavior on Twitter, including calling fans of anime "mentally disabled," discriminatory remarks about Chinese and Korean anime fans, and attacking his former cast members, which resulted in him being temporarily suspended from Twitter in 2018.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yamacane0901/) | [Blog (jp)](https://ameblo.jp/kanku0901/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcZ_aVrm0ux7Jw2G5jgq6Gw/)

In 2006, he was selected to be the chief episode director of [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/), after which he became well known among anime fans for the ending dance theme he choreographed. He was to make his full directorial debut with [Lucky Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1887/), but was replaced after four episodes due to "performance issues." In a later radio interview, Yamamoto confirmed he was fired by Kyoto Animation and unsuccessfully attempted to win back his job. 

Yamamoto has threatened to quit his career in anime production six times over the years. In May 2019, Yamamoto vowed never to "work on anything related to animation again" after finishing [Hakubo](https://anilist.co/anime/98784/). He has become notorious for his incendiary behavior on Twitter, including calling fans of anime "mentally disabled," discriminatory remarks about Chinese and Korean anime fans, and attacking his former cast members, which resulted in him being temporarily suspended from Twitter in 2018.

Yasuhiro Takemoto studied animation at the Yoyogi Animation Academy. After graduating, he started working at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/Kyoto-Animation) for almost his entire animation career, joining the company in 1996. At the company, Yasuhiro was considered one of the most reliable and trustworthy members of the staff. [Nurse Witch Komugi](https://anilist.co/anime/615/Nurse-Witch-Komugichan/) was his directorial debut​ and [Full Metal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/Full-Metal-Panic-Fumoffu/) his first solo directorial debut.

He died in the arson attack at Kyoto Animation's Studio 1 on July 18, 2019.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dochibibi) Yukiko Horiguchi is an animator, illustrator and character designer formerly belonging to Kyoto Animation. She joined Kyoto Animation in 2003 after graduating from a junior college (tanki daigaku). She started as inbetweener on Shin-Chan, before making a debut as key animator on the KyoAni in-house OVA Munto. In 2007 she was given the chance to design characters for the anime adaptation of the Lucky Star yon-koma manga. Horiguchi is particularly known for the shape she gives her drawings, resulting in a certain roundness and the distinctly fine outline and peculiar shading. Her characters appear to be very child-like and cute, and full of energy, which is a major appeal to the fans. The illustrator [BUNBUN](https://anilist.co/staff/112785) is her younger brother.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/dochibibi) Yukiko Horiguchi is an animator, illustrator and character designer formerly belonging to Kyoto Animation. She joined Kyoto Animation in 2003 after graduating from a junior college (tanki daigaku). She started as inbetweener on Shin-Chan, before making a debut as key animator on the KyoAni in-house OVA Munto. In 2007 she was given the chance to design characters for the anime adaptation of the Lucky Star yon-koma manga. Horiguchi is particularly known for the shape she gives her drawings, resulting in a certain roundness and the distinctly fine outline and peculiar shading. Her characters appear to be very child-like and cute, and full of energy, which is a major appeal to the fans. The illustrator [BUNBUN](https://anilist.co/staff/112785) is her younger brother.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B1%B1%E7%94%B0%E5%B0%9A%E5%AD%90) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naoko_Yamada)

Naoko Yamada is a Japanese animator and director. She worked at [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/) from 2004 to 2020. 

Yamada enjoyed drawing as a child and would copy images from the [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/) and [Dragon Ball](https://anilist.co/anime/223/) series. She joined the volleyball club in primary school and the tennis and photography clubs in high school. At the Kyoto University of Art and Design, she studied oil painting and was a member of the special effects club. She intended to work in film after university, but instead decided to join Kyoto Animation after seeing an advertisement. Her first assignment at the studio was drawing in between frames for [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/), which Kyoto Animation helped produce. She was eventually promoted to a key animator for [Air](https://anilist.co/anime/101/).

After working as an episode director of [Clannad](https://anilist.co/anime/2167/), she was asked to make her chief directorial debut with [K-ON!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680/), an adaptation of a slice-of-life manga. The series was very successful, spurring a second season and a film. In 2013, she directed [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417/), and followed it with the film [Tamako Love Story](https://anilist.co/anime/20519/) in 2014. For Tamako Love Story, she was awarded the New Face Award at the Japan Media Arts Festival. She storyboarded the entire film herself, and also wrote the lyrics for the opening theme song, “Everybody Loves Somebody.”

Yamada's next project was the feature film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954/), an adaptation of [Yoshitoki Ooima](https://anilist.co/staff/105951/)’s manga by the same name. The film reflected on elements of bullying and physical impairment in Japan. The film opened at #2 in the Japanese Box Office and grossed a total of ¥2.3 billion (~$21.7m USD), the 19th highest-grossing film in Japan in 2016. The film also received multiple award nominations, including Best Animation Film in the Mainichi Film Awards and the Excellent Animation of the Year in the Japan Academy Prize.

For Yamada, the most important part of being a director is to observe people. She describes herself as a "method" director, emphasizing the minds of the characters.

(Source: Wikipedia)
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/田村せいき)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田和美)

Kazumi Ikeda is a Japanese animator and character designer currently affiliated with [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/). She joined KyoAni in 1995 after graduating from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and transferred to the studio's Osaka branch [Animation Do](https://anilist.co/studio/929/Animation-Do) when it was established in 2000.

She is best known for doing the character designs in KyoAni's anime adaptations of Key's most prominent visual novels, [Kanon](https://anilist.co/anime/1530/Kanon-2006/) and [Clannad](https://anilist.co/anime/2167/Clannad/), marking also her debut as chief animation director on the Kanon remake.

She has no blood relationship with late [Shouko Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/102736/).
